reviewText: As 6-7 year old black child growing up near Charleston SC in 1971-72, I have a special place in my heart for this cartoon. This show told us that it was okay to dream big and that we could live out whatever fanstasy we had about what we wanted to be when we grew up (of course I did not analyze it this way it the time, but it was deep in our subconscious in retrospect). For years fans of the show had to settle with , ahem..."unauthroized versions," but now the wait is over!As for the content of the show, nostalgia  and animation quality aside, its not as bad as some say. "It All Started With" (which had the dubious historical disctinction of airing Sept. 11, 1971, during the Attica riots and 30 years to the day before....) is the legendary PR tale that was widely believed at the time of Diana Ross discovering the J5. This is actually quite comical as the J5 con their way into the studio and the Berry Gordy caricature is amusing. "Cinderjackson" has Mike desiring to go out on a date with a "princess of pop" that eerily presages Whitney Houston (the afro-wearing "hairy godfather"-NOW HOOOOLD IT! is his catchprhase-is hilarious). "The Wizard of Soul" has the J5 in the land of Oz, which also predicts "The Wiz" by some seven years! "Groovatron," a funky soul-dancing robot, appeared some three years before the J5's "Dancing Machine" and the popular "robot" dance! "Rasho Jackson," as noted on another website, predicts the events that led to the actual breakup of the J5 a few decades later! The writers of this show were far more on the ball than anyone realized at the time.One fascinating episode, "Ray & Charles Superstars" features the J5's pet mice Ray & Charles (clever, eh?) being discovered by an animator named McKay Windsor (interesting inside joke-Windsor McKay was the founder of modern animation) and made into tempermental cartoon superstar divas. Not only is this ep a lot of fun, it includes a segment of Mike and Marlon going into a cartoon studio and "McKay Windsor" showing the boys how cartoons are made. As a child, this educated me and many other children to the process. "Pinestock USA" (a Woodstock takeoff) is also a pro-environmentalist tale that makes its point with good humor and music to boot. "Who's Hoozis" is an almost eerie tale of Mike's encounter with a reculsive and eccentric millionaire. Kids then (or now) would be unaware that this is a spoof of Howard Hughes, who died a couple of years later from his isolation.The final irony in this show so full of ironies is that one of the speaking voices for the J5 was done by Edumund Sylvers, who was a year or so away from being a member of the Sylvers-another family R&B; band who provided serious (but friendly) competition with the J5 a few years later! Sadly, Edmund died a few years ago of lung cancer.While the quality of the animation itself may leave something to be desired, the series remains entertaining in the same way that "A Hard Day's Night," "The Monkees," and the Archie cartoons remain timelessly entertaining in spite of dated elements in the way that they capture the spirit of young people accomplishing their dreams.

reviewText: While it can be hard to imagine the King of Pop as as a member of a group: Before there was Michael, there was the Jackson 5. Without the Jackson 5, we wouldn't have such timeless classics as "Dancing Machine", "Rockin' Robin", and "ABC". The Jackson 5 has left a legacy that has been overshadowed by the most famous of the brothers.But now the group is together again like it hasn't been since 1972! In their very own animated TV series.The sound and visuals are amazing. The colors really pop and some will say the animation is cheap and dated, I think it matches perfectly with the time that the cartoon originally aired. This is nostalgia of a time long past, packed onto 2 disks.Each show has two songs (plus the always popular opening theme ABC). And in each the group solves a problem. This is a pretty common theme in cartoons from the 70's and 80's: teach kids that they can make a difference and it is ok to dream. This is something missing from most of today's cartoon fare that focus more on combat, looks, or popularity.My children (9 and 12) also liked it. My daughter especially got into watching it with me. She has been on a bit of a retro kick lately and really liked the slang of the time: groovy, can you dig it, and funky have found their way into her vocabulary.I give this dvd set 4 stars. I recommend it for anyone with children that they would like to introduce to a little bit of music history or for someone that liked the show and wants to give it another go round.Note: I was given a copy of this in exchange for an honest review.

reviewerName: Chris Swanson "I'm just this guy, you know?"
reviewText: (special thanks to the publisher for providing me with a review copy!)In theory I remember watching The Jackson 5ive. It began airing around the time I was born, so I'm sure that at some point when I was a wee lad, I caught it in syndication. I had to have. But I don't actually remember seeing it before, so maybe I missed it. The good thing is that lets me approach this set without any nostalgia. The bad thing is that it lets me approach this set without any nostalgia.In this set, you get, on four discs, both the blu ray and DVD version of the complete series. You get every episode with 46 different songs, and a helpful book that helps you locate exactly where each song is, so if you want to watch a specific one, you know where to go for it. This is a good thing, since the music is definitely the highlight of this series.I will say that the songs on these discs sound just great, and likely sound better than they did when they were first broadcast. The video quality is also excellent, even if the images themselves...well, look, it was the 1970s, ok? Most of us understand that it wasn't a great time for certain forms of art, and animation is one of those. The whole thing looks exceptionally psychedelic, and not in a good way. Go to YouTube and look at some clips and you'll see what I mean.Beyond the animation, the stories are also really strange. In the first episode, for example, we have the boys trying to keep Michael's pink snake from terrorizing Dianna Ross. And by "pink snake" I mean a snake that is pink, because of course. Michael Jackson also has a pair of pet mice named Ray and Charles because why not. Oh, and the whole thing has a laugh track, because, you know, that makes sense.What you don't get, sadly, is anything in the way of special features. Now I'm sure there weren't a lot of things they could have done in the way of special features here, but surely a commentary or two would have been nice, or perhaps some interviews. As it stands, this creates a package that's great for kids and hardcore Jackson 5 fans, but not so much for other people.And I suppose ultimately, that's how I'll describe this. It's for the hardcore Jackson 5 fans for those people who have kids and want to give them something safe and harmless that has a good soundtrack. If you're looking for anything deeper than that, you'll be severely disappointed. But if that's what you want, I'm sure you'll be happy!
summary: A great kids' show for kids, but probably not something for adult collectors

reviewText: Throughout the early part of the 1970's, the Jackson 5 were the mainstays and influence in the pop music world.  Because of their music and universal appeal, they were considered by many in the USA and around the world to be the first real pop teen idols of the psychadelic era.Now, for the first time, this wonderful collection of cartoons from the JACKSON 5 CARTOON SHOW is here on DVD.  I remember the time when I watched the adventures--and comedic musical misadventures--of Michael, Marlon, Jermaine, Tito and Jackie in my big sisters' bedroom every Saturday morning.  And, it brings back the genuine standards of what Saturday Morning entertainment should be.If you love a great marriage of music and animation, get this collection.  You will not take your eyes off every rocking and soulful minute!
summary: Fab Five of Seventies Pop and Soul
Title: N/A

reviewerName: David Addis "King Of The Ol' Skool"
reviewText: Remember when Saturday mornings were once Saturday mornings? Or when Soul music and Motown once were what they were? This DVD answers both questions at once. I remember this from the early part of the 70's (as well as other cartoons I can recall vividly. BTW-The Osmond Brothers also had a cartoon series, but its whereabouts are unknown to this day). The troupe laugh and dance their way through various adventures (and misadventures), singing their top hits. The Jackson 5 were one of the flagships from the Motown fleet, battling with Atlantic Records for soul supremacy. From Gary, Indiana, they became a powerhouse for the Detroit-based label, and the rest, as it has been said, is music history. This item is a definite absolute MUST for the die-hard Michael Jackson fan (his fans will be thrilled to see this come along). The creative geniuses at Classic Media (The Rankin-Bass classic Christmas four DVD set) should be happy for what they have done, and it is the impossible where this cartoon is concerned. I enjoyed watching it, just like it was yesterday (and when we were all kids ourselves). I am glad this series lives again. Michael Jackson (rest in peace) is himself proud and this set does so in his honor! The songs have been remastered for the set. This reviewer can also say he is proud!
summary: "Jackson 5 Animated Series"-A true treasure for the Soul Boomers! Salsoul Connection Ol' Skool Rarities!

reviewText: There really is nothing like a blast from the past and Classic Media has done it in style. I'm from the generation who actually looked forward to watching the Jackson 5ive on Saturday mornings. Mind you, we only had thirteen channels then and if you wanted to watch another one, you had to get up to change it. There was no such thing as a remote and cell phones ... well, that was something you'd see on the futuristic Star Trek series. The Jackson 5ive series was short, but very sweet, running from September 11, 1971 to October 14, 1972. It later resurfaced briefly during the 1980s.The remastered songs and the film have definitely improved the series, but there's still that old laugh track that gives in that nostalgic, retro feel. I played the series on an old surround sound DVD player and the sound was awesome. Not quite like the old stereo sound, but the series is now ready for yet another generation to enjoy. The packaging is quite appealing, especially the discs which resemble 45 rpm records, which most of the songs ended up on in collections. Somehow the bright rainbow colors bring back the over-the-top vibrant feel the Jackson Five used to bring out in people.If you're anxious to revisit the fictionalized lives of Titom Marlon, Jermaine, Jackie, and Michael Jackson along with a host of other "guest" stars, here are the episodes along with the songs included with each one:DISC 1:Episode 1:"It All Started With ..."* ABC* Goin' Back to IndianaEpisode 2:"Pinestock, U.S.A"* I'll be There* The Young FolksEpisode 3:"Drafted"* I Want You Back* 2-4-6-8Episode 4:"Mistaken Identity"* I'll Bet You* Sixteen CandlesEpisode 5:"Bongo, Baby, Bongo"* My Little Baby* It's Great to be HereEpisode 6:"The Winner's Circle"* The Love You Save* How Funky is Your ChickenEpisode 7:"Cinderjackson"* Reach In* Can I See You in the Morning?Episode 8:"The Wizard of Soul"* The Love I Saw in You Was Just a Mirage* Oh How HappyEpisode 9:"The Tiny Five"* The Wall* I Will Find a WayEpisode 10:"The Groovatron"* Maybe Tomorrow* NobodyEpisode 11:"Ray & Charles: Superstars"* (Come `Round Here) I'm the One You Need* (We've Got) Blue SkiesEpisode 12:"Farmer Jacksons"* My Cherie Amour* Honey ChileDISC 2:Episode 12:"Jackson Island"* Ready or Not (Here I Come)* La La (Means I Love You)Episode 14:"The Michael Look"* Darling Dear* Don't Know Why (I Love You)Episode 15:"Jackson Street, U.S.A."* Petals* She's GoodEpisode 16:"Rasho-Jackson"* One More Chance* I Found that GirlEpisode: 17"A Rare Pearl"* Never Can Say Goodbye* Mama's PearlEpisode 18:"Who's Hoozie"* Sugar Daddy* I Wanna Be Where You AreEpisode 20:"Groove to the Chief"* I'm So Happy* In Our Small WayEpisode 21:"Michael in Wonderland"* Got to be There* MariaEpisode 22:"Jackson and the Beanstalk"* Love is Here* Girl Don't Take Your Love From MeEpisode 23""The Opening Act"* Little Bitty Pretty One* If I have to Move a MountainWhen I watched these after so many years, I can still tell you which ones were my favorites and which were not. What makes it especially nice, in addition to the remastering, is the fact that this is the complete series. There's nothing that galls me any more than split series ... you have to buy one and then the other to complete your collection. There are only two discs, but they are full-length episodes. This memory making series will definitely be a classic!This collection courtesy of Classic Media.
summary: This is a "groovy" blast into the past with Tito, Marlon, Jermaine, Jackie and, of course, Michael Jackson!

reviewText: I watched this with my 9 year old grandson and he enjoyed it. He liked the cartoons and the music. I thought the music was fantastic and I even heard songs for the first time that I didn't even know that the Jackson Five had sung. For me though the cartoons were just too old fashioned and just not anywhere close to the quality of today's cartoon or CGI generated animations. You probably have forgotten like I had what they looked like 41 years ago. My grandson liked the cartoon's storyline and the way the characters acted in the cartoons and he thought they were funny.The music is top notch and the sound is so good it seems to be a digitally mastered CD with 46 songs. The combo comes with two Blu-ray DVDs and two normal DVD's. My grandson really liked it so I am sure your children will too. I rated it a 4 star but my grandson rated it 5 stars. If you loved the Jackson Five then this is a collector's item for you. If you have children then they will enjoy it and like it as much as you did back then.I was supplied an evaluation sample and I promised to provide a fair and honest review.
summary: Get it for the great music and the enjoyment you will have remembering the Jackson Five and Michael!

reviewText: It's been a very long time since I watched these cartoons. Boy did it take me back, well too far. It's funny how you look at them differently when you are an adult and a generation or two away. These are so reminiscent of the time. Lots of rainbows, mod shapes and flowers, a overload of colors and movement and weak story lines. But they were and still are, entertaining.While watching with my kids (ages 8 and 13) we laughed and laughed. When I told them I used to watch them, they replied, "That explains a lot." The episodes start out with a summary plot of the Jackson 5 story, including the voice of Diana Ross. The snake (Rosie) and mice (Ray and Charles) become regulars and there is sometimes a moral theme that still resonates today.These are fun to watch, but probably only a few episodes at a time. Or it's ABC-123 overload. There are well-known Jackson 5 songs featured along with quite a few unheard songs.I'm not sure the Blu-Ray is necessary but the fact that this set has both Blu-Ray and DVD is a great bonus. And this is packed with 23 episodes and tons of Jackson 5 songs is added value.This was great fun to watch and share with my kids. Even though cartoons these days seem more sophisticated (well, that's up for debate) they remained interested and entertained. So it's time to bring another generation into the legend of the Jackson 5!I was provided a copy for review.
summary: After Watching with My Kids, They Finally Understand
Title: N/A

reviewText: The nostalgia factor can be a show's best friend or its worst enemy.  I can easily imagine that the viewers who got caught up in the animated adventures of the Jackson Five during the short lived show from 1971 "Jackson 5ive" will be thrilled to revisit their old friends.  However, let's face it, the show aired for 23 episodes over forty years ago.  That means that this DVD release will likely be viewed through very modern eyes both by those who have never heard of it and by those who might not even be familiar with the Jackson Five.  As I sat down to this flight of fancy, I immediately recognized the trademark psychedelic look of the time, the cheesy dialogue, and the infectious pop soundtrack.  In short, it was pretty much exactly what I expected.  That doesn't necessarily mean that it was good or bad in my estimation.  It simply means that what you get out of "Jackson 5ive" is directly proportional to your expectations going in.  And in truth, I'm not sure modern kids will be able to appreciate the madness as much as their parents.Michael, Tito, Jermaine, Jackie and Marlon are portrayed as the leads of this series.  The plots might have been slight and silly, but there are some intriguing episodes as well.  Most successful for my taste is the premiere episode.  Featuring a fictionalized account of how Diana Ross discovered the kids, it was kind of kicky to see how this paralleled real life.  Other shows strayed into fantasy territory, however, and are more hit and miss.  A common theme had Michael (the youngest) getting into some kind of mischief that the gang had to extricate themselves from before the episode ended.  Again, the better episodes should be more greatly appreciated by those with a working knowledge of the kids and their history.  Each episode has odd music video segments inserted into the story lines that might be reminiscent of the hallucinogenic experiences one might encounter while ingesting popular substances of the era.The 23 included episodes with the prominent songs:1)  It All Started With. . . (ABC, Goin' Back to Indiana)2)  Pinestock, U.S.A. (I'll Be There,  The Young Folks)3)  Drafted (I Want You Back, 2-4-6-8)4)  Mistaken Identity (I'll Bet You, Sixteen Candles)5)  Bongo, Baby, Bongo (My Little Baby,  It's Great To Be Here)6)  The Winner's Circle (The Love You Save, How Funky Is Your Chicken?)7) CinderJackson (Reach In, Can I See You In the Morning?)8) The Wizard of Soul ( The Love I Saw In You Was Just A Mirage, Oh How Happy)9) The Tiny Five (The Wall, I Will Find A Way)10) The Groovatron  (Maybe Tomorrow, Nobody)11) Ray & Charles: Superstars (I'm the One You Need, Blue Skies)12) Farmer Jacksons (My Cherie Amour, Honey Chile)13) Jackson Island (Ready or Not, La La)14) The Michael Look (Darling Dear,Don't Know Why)15) Jackson Street, U.S.A. (Petals, She's Good)16) Rasho-Jackson (One More Chance, I Found That Girl)17) A Rare Pearl (Never Can Say Goodbye, Mama's Pearl)18) Who's Hoozis (Rockin' Robin, Wings of My Love)19) Michael White (Sugar Daddy, I Wanna Be Where You Are)20) Groove to the Chief (I'm So Happy, In Our Small Way)21) Michael in Wonderland (Got to Be There, Maria)22) Jackson and the Beanstalk (Love is Here, Girl Don't Take Your Love From Me)23) The Opening Act (Little Bitty Pretty One, If I Have to Move A Mountain)The major selling point, of course, is the music.  Featuring many of the group's hit songs (from the late sixties primarily), the set is boasting that there are 46 remastered songs.  As you can see, that's two per episode.  Not every song is a classic, but the selection should more than satisfy those with fond remembrances of The Five.  On the video presentation, the Blu-ray looks clean and vibrant.  The bold use of colors really looks great and transitions better than the actual audio quality (which only seems enhanced on the musical interludes).  This is a four disc set with two discs being Blu-ray and two standard DVD format.As a time capsule replete with slang, pop culture references of the age, and the annoying laugh track cueing expected guffaws--"Jackson 5ive" is an interesting curiosity.  Four stars for those seeking nostalgia and classic music, three stars for a new audience unfamiliar with The Jackson Five.  KGHarris, 1/13.
summary: Psychedelic Seventies Silliness: This Cartoon Boasts Great Nostalgia And Music, But May Not Translate To Modern Kids

reviewText: I received this set directly from the publisher, and hoped that it would be as great as it was in my memory of 40 years ago.  The Jacksons burned up the music charts when I was a tween and of course Michael owned the charts in the 80s.  Every kid I knew watched the Jackson 5 cartoon on TV, and we sang their songs on the school bus.I'm happy to say that this 2-DVD set is every bit as good as I remember.  The colors are bold and the sound crystal clear.  It's actually better than when it appeared on TV because of the improved sound and picture capability of today's technology.  Add in the bonus of no TV commercials and you've got a perfect trip down memory lane.  All 46 of the remastered songs sound great!Yes, the story lines are sappy, but they were a product of their times and I like them much better than the TV shows full of sexuality and bad language targeted towards our kids today.This collection will probably appeal most to children of the 70s or fans of the Jackson 5 and their music, but I'm happy that the old shows have been re-released on DVD format.
summary: Groovy!  As great as I remember them from my childhood!

reviewText: Classic Media has released some great material to Blu-ray recently, including some of the most beloved Rankin/Bass classics like Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer and Frosty the Snowman. I consider myself a big fan of Rankin/Bass, though I am no expert by any means. In fact, I hadn't even heard of this show, the Jackson Five animated series! This Saturday morning show ran for just 23 episodes in the early 70's, and, being a cartoon nut in general, I was eager to see it! I grew up a fan of Michael Jackson as a small child in the 80's when his solo career was at its height, and I always enjoyed the music of the Jackson Five too, though it was before my time, like this show! Having finally checked it out thanks to this new Blu-ray set, I can honestly say, this cartoon is a lot of fun to watch!Okay, so it's your basic, contrived, "popular group (musical or otherwise) in wacky situations" show of the time, not unlike a lot of Hanna-Barbera shows. It also unfortunately doesn't use the voices of the actual Jackson Five for the character dialogue (though Diana Ross makes an appearance in the first episode). However, each episode does have two real Jackson Five songs, and the goofy plots are more humorous than you might expect. The dated slang really adds to that. This is one of those shows that is a great time machine, whether you grew up with it or not. If you have any interest in the Jackson Five, cartoons, or the 70's, this should hold some appeal and fascination for you. I have bought some shows of the time in the past that I couldn't watch more than a couple episodes of in a single sitting. The music here (46 remastered Jackson Five songs) really does make the difference, and the playfulness of the 5 lead characters really is enjoyable.Classic Media does a beautiful job presenting the 23 episodes here in this 4-disc Blu-ray set (2 discs are the show on Blu-ray, 2 discs are the show on Standard DVD, which is handy since not everyone has Blu-Ray yet, especially for their computers or portable players). The packaging is gorgeously 70's and the discs look like little records. The episodes look great, though they hold no bonus features. Then again, finding bonus features for this may have been a tall order. Here is a list of the episodes:Disc 1It All Started With...Pinestock, U.S.A.DraftedMistaken IdentityBongo, Baby, bongoThe Winner's CircleCinderjacksonThe Wizard of SoulThe Tiny FiveThe GroovatronRay and Charles: SuperstarsFarmer JacksonsDisc 2Jackson IslandThe Michael LookJackson Street, U.S.A.Rasho JacksonA Rare PearlWho's HoozisMichael WhiteGroove to the ChiefMichael in WonderlandJackson and the BeanstalkThe Opening ActThese episodes follow the Jackson Five band around on tour as they get into some wacky adventures, some very fantasy-based, though the first episode is about them becoming musicians and so is a teeny tiny bit less wacky of a concept. As I said, I do recommend this set to anyone who is a fan of the Jackson Five, cartoons, Rankin/Bass or the 70's. It was more enjoyable than I'd guessed, and I look forward to putting it on again!
summary: A True Pop Culture Time Capsule!

reviewText: I welcomed the opportunity to preview this set of Jackson Five animated stories from over forty years ago. Hard to believe it's been that long. Despite the age of the animations, the sound, color, and clarity of the picture are first rate. I was impressed by the vividness of the colors and the richness while watching the animations on both my laptop and our HD television.Most of the plots are timeless. The boys are confronted with a problem or a villain and figure out a way to solve the problem or defeat the nemesis. In each episode two songs are integrated into the plot seamlessly and impressively. The style of the animation at times reminds me of Rocky and Bullwinkle with amplified color or the Beatles' Rubber Submarine movie. Many of the themes are still topical today like destruction of trees and natural environments and kindness to animals.The 70s styles and expressions were nostalgic for me as were the songs and the language. It's been many a year since I've heard phrases like: I'm hip, Let's slide, Right on, Can you dig it, Cool cats, Funky, Swinging, and Ready to jive. It was also amusing to see one of the characters playing music on a reel to reel tape player. I think even young viewers will get a kick our of the language and the ever present bell bottoms, tie dyed shirts, and puffy Afro hairstyles.This Potato Head thinks that the Jackson Five Animated Series can be enjoyed by a whole new generation of viewers who haven't heard the music of the Jackson Five and who haven't seen the psychedelic animation style of the 70s. And the music? It's just as enjoyable now as it was in the 70s.Note - I don't recommend watching an entire DVD's episodes in one sitting back to back to back to back etc. like I did. Each episode begins with the A-B-C theme song that, as much as I like it, eventually grows tiresome with so much repetition.

reviewText: Been waiting a long time for this to finally come out...great packaging great sound....a must have for Jackson 5 fans...
Title: N/A

reviewText: THE JACKSON 5IVE: THE COMPLETE ANIMATED SERIES brings together both seasons (23 episodes total) of the JACKSON 5IVE ANIMATED SERIES. In addition to having the members of the Jackson Five (Michael, Tito, Jermaine, Jackie, and Marlon) the episodes also feature Michael’s animals: pet rats, Ray and Charles, and a pink snake named Rosie. In a typical episode one of the brothers (usually Michael) gets into some kind of trouble, there’s a musical interlude, the Jackson Five work together to get out of trouble, there’s another musical interlude, and then everything is wrapped up. Each episode features two songs sung by the Jackson Five. These songs usually don’t have anything to do with the cartoon and are there to feature the music of the Jackson Five.The episodes in the series are:Season One:1. “It All Started With…” – introduces the five brothers and how they got together. Diana Ross makes a guest appearance. Features the songs “ABC” and “Goin’ Back to Indiana.”2. “Pinestock, U.S.A.” – the Jackson Five plays at an outdoor concert but discovers there’s a mean group of lumberjacks ready to level the forest. Features the songs “I’ll Be There” and “The Young Folks.”3. “Drafted” – Marlon and Michael are accidently drafted into the service. Features the songs “I Want You Back” and “2-4-6-8.”4. “Mistaken Identity” – Driving out west to Las Vegas, the brothers get sidetracked in an Old West town and are mistaken for a gang of bandits. Features the songs “I’ll Bet You” and “16 Candles.”5. “Bong, Baby, Bongo” – Michael becomes adopted by a female gorilla. Features the songs “My Little Baby” and “It’s Great to Be Here.”6. “The Winners’ Circle” – Michael is tricked into buying a lazy horse and bets more than he bargained for on it. Features the songs “The Love You Save” and “How Funky Is Your Chicken.”7. “CinderJackson” – Michael wants to attend a birthday party for the Princess of Pop, Samantha Christie, but gets sick and can’t go. That is until he gets a gift from his Hairy Godfather. Features the songs “Reach In” and “Can I See You in the Morning.”8. “The Wizard of Soul” – Michael wanders into a mystical oasis called the Land of Soul and with the help of Wizard of Oz-like family members tries to find the Wizard of Soul and get back to his real brothers in time for their performance. Features the songs “The Love I Saw in You Was Just a Mirage” and “Oh How Happy.”9. “The Tiny Five” – the Jacksons are shrunk by a mischievous salesman and have to find a way to reverse their miniaturization. Features the songs “The Wall” and “I Will Find a Way.10. “The Groovatron” – the Jacksons are exhausted and Marlon invents a robot to stand in for them at performances. The robot is stolen and is used by a salesman in an attempt to replace The Jackson Five. Features the songs “Maybe Tomorrow” and “Nobody.”11. “Ray & Charles: Superstars” – Michael’s pet rats Ray and Charles become Hollywood celebrities. Features the songs “(Come Round Here) I’m the One You Need” and “(We’ve Got) Blue Skies.”12. “Farmer Jacksons” – the Jackson take a break from touring and buy a farm. Features the songs “My Cherie Amour” and “Honey Chile.”13. “Jackson Island” – on the way to Hawaii, the Jacksons crash into an island and Michael gets knocked on the head by a coconut. Features the songs “Ready or Not (Here I Come)” and “La La Means I Love You.”14. “The Michael Look” – Michael’s stage clothes get lost on a trip to London. Features the songs “Darling Dear” and “I Don’ Know Why I Love You.”15. “Jackson Street, U.S.A.” – the Mayor of Gary, Indiana declares that a street in the city will be renamed the “Jackson 5 Boulevard.” Features the songs “Petals” and “She’s Good.”16. “Rasho-Jackson” – the Jacksons break up after their car stalls and go their separate ways. The episode predicts how each of the brothers will end up twenty years later. Features the songs “One More Chance” and “I Found That Girl.”17. “A Rare Pearl” – the brothers swear off girls but on their next tour flight they all become infatuated with a female flight attendant named Jacqueline Pearl. Features the songs “Never Can Say Goodbye” and “Mama’s Pearl.”Season 218. “Who’s Hoozis?” – the Jacksons are scheduled to perform an outdoor concert, but Michael discovers a talking “blue bird” (a blues singing bluebird). Features the songs “Rockin’ Robin” and “Wings of My Love.”19. “Michael White” – Michael bumps his head in a bicycle accident and dreams he is a storybook prince. Features the songs “Sugar Daddy” and “I Wanna Be Where You Are.”20. “Groove to the Chief” – Michael fantasizes what it would be like to be the Mayor of Los Angeles and his Hairy Godfather makes it so. Features the songs “I’m So Happy” and “In Our Small Way.”21. “Michael in Wonderland” – Michael falls unconscious while riding a roller coaster and dreams he is in Wonderland. Features the songs “Got to Be There” and “Maria (You Were the Only One).”22. “Jackson and the Beanstalk” – Michael finds some magic beans that grow a giant beanstalk outside the Jackson apartment in Indiana. Features the songs “Love Is Here (And Now You’re Gone)” and “Girl Don’t Take Your Love from Me.”23. “The Opening Act” – a promoter books the brothers on a heavy radio tour schedule while trying to find them an opening act for their upcoming concert. Features the songs “Little Bitty Pretty One” and “If I Have to Move a Mountain.”In terms of animation and storylines, THE JACKSON 5IVE is typical of several animated tv shows from the period: there’s the corny jokes followed by the canned laugh track that often doesn’t fit with the jokes being told, silly dialogue, and animated segments filled with psychedelic imagery. I remember many of these elements watching re-runs 1970s cartoon in the early 1980s. It’s not so bad except those elements are used in every single episode. Those who watched the show or similar shows when they were younger will probably really enjoy watching THE JACKSON 5IVE: THE COMPLETE ANIMATED SERIES. However, anyone else might find the series a bit dull and repetitive.
Title: N/A
